prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Gilbert Blythe: Charming and mischievous, quick-witted in conversation, competitive yet kind-hearted, with a knack for teasing those he admires.
Marilla Cuthbert: Practical and stern, with a dry wit and deep sense of duty, masking a heart that is far softer than she lets on.
Rachel Lynde: Blunt and opinionated, never hesitating to voice her thoughts, but ultimately well-meaning and fiercely loyal to those she cares for.
Anne Shirley: Imaginative and expressive, speaking in vivid, poetic language, full of enthusiasm and deep emotions, with a tendency for dramatic flourishes.


Dialogue History: Marilla Cuthbert: Oh, Anne, I could get on real well if you were here, I know. But I can't let you sacrifice yourself so for me. It would be terrible.
Anne Shirley: Nonsense!
Anne Shirley: There is no sacrifice. Nothing could be worse than giving up Green Gables--nothing could hurt me more. We must keep the dear old place. My mind is quite made up, Marilla. I'm _not_ going to Redmond; and I _am_ going to stay here and teach. Don't you worry about me a bit.
Marilla Cuthbert: But your ambitions--and--
Anne Shirley: I'm just as ambitious as ever. Only, I've changed the object of my ambitions. I'm going to be a good teacher--and I'm going to save your eyesight. Besides, I mean to study at home here and take a little college course all by myself. Oh, I've dozens of plans, Marilla. I've been thinking them out for a week. I shall give life here my best, and I believe it will give its best to me in return. When I left Queen's my future seemed to stretch out before me like a straight road. I thought I could see along it for many a milestone. Now there is a bend in it. I don't know what lies around the bend, but I'm going to believe that the best does. It has a fascination of its own, that bend, Marilla. I wonder how the road beyond it goes--what there is of green glory and soft, checkered light and shadows--what new landscapes--what new beauties--what curves and hills and valleys further on.
Marilla Cuthbert: I don't feel as if I ought to let you give it up,
Anne Shirley: But you can't prevent me. I'm sixteen and a half, as Mrs. Lynde once told me, Oh, Marilla, don't you go pitying me. I don't like to be pitied, and there is no need for it. I'm heart glad over the very thought of staying at dear Green Gables. Nobody could love it as you and I do--so we must keep it.
Marilla Cuthbert: You blessed girl! I feel as if you'd given me new life. I guess I ought to stick out and make you go to college--but I know I can't, so I ain't going to try. I'll make it up to you though, Anne.
Rachel Lynde: I declare I'm getting glad to sit down. I've been on my feet all day, and two hundred pounds is a good bit for two feet to carry round. It's a great blessing not to be fat, Marilla. I hope you appreciate it. Well, Anne, I hear you've given up your notion of going to college. I was real glad to hear it. You've got as much education now as a woman can be comfortable with. I don't believe in girls going to college with the men and cramming their heads full of Latin and Greek and all that nonsense.
Anne Shirley: But I'm going to study Latin and Greek just the same, Mrs. Lynde, I'm going to take my Arts course right here at Green Gables, and study everything that I would at college.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Rachel Lynde: Anne Shirley, you'll kill yourself.

Anne Shirley: But you can't prevent me. I'm sixteen and a half, as Mrs. Lynde once told me, Oh, Marilla, don't you go pitying me. I don't like to be pitied, and there is no need for it. Marilla Cuthbert: You blessed girl! I feel as if you'd given me new life. I guess I ought to stick out and make you go to college--but I know I can't, so I ain't going to try. I'll make it up to you though, Anne.
Rachel Lynde: I declare I'm getting glad to sit down. I've been on my feet all day, and two hundred pounds is a good bit for two feet to carry round. It's a great blessing not to be fat, Marilla. I hope you appreciate it. Well, Anne, I hear you've given up your notion of going to college. I was real glad to hear it. You've got as much education now as a woman can be comfortable with. I don't believe in girls going to college with the men and cramming their heads full of Latin and Greek and all that nonsense.
Anne Shirley: But I'm going to study Latin and Greek just the same, Mrs. Lynde, I'm going to take my Arts course right here at Green Gables, and study everything that I would at college.
Rachel Lynde: Anne Shirley, you'll kill yourself.
Anne Shirley: Not a bit of it. I shall thrive on it. Oh, I'm not going to overdo things. As ?Josiah Allen's wife,' says, I shall be ?mejum'. But I'll have lots of spare time in the long winter evenings, and I've no vocation for fancy work. I'm going to teach over at Carmody, you know.
Rachel Lynde: I don't know it. I guess you're going to teach right here in Avonlea. The trustees have decided to give you the school.
Anne Shirley: Mrs. Lynde! Why, I thought they had promised it to Gilbert Blythe!

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Rachel Lynde: So they did. But as soon as Gilbert heard that you had applied for it he went to them--they had a business meeting at the school last night, you know--and told them that he withdrew his application, and suggested that they accept yours. He said he was going to teach at White Sands. Of course he knew how much you wanted to stay with Marilla, and I must say I think it was real kind and thoughtful in him, that's what. Real self-sacrificing, too, for he'll have his board to pay at White Sands, and everybody knows he's got to earn his own way through college. So the trustees decided to take you. I was tickled to death when Thomas came home and told me.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Marilla Cuthbert: Practical and stern, with a dry wit and deep sense of duty, masking a heart that is far softer than she lets on.
Matthew Cuthbert: Quiet and deeply kind, speaking sparingly but always with sincerity, preferring to listen rather than lead conversations.
Anne Shirley: Imaginative and expressive, speaking in vivid, poetic language, full of enthusiasm and deep emotions, with a tendency for dramatic flourishes.


Dialogue History: Anne Shirley: Oh, I put it back on the bureau. I hadn't it on a minute. Truly, I didn't mean to meddle, Marilla. I didn't think about its being wrong to go in and try on the brooch; but I see now that it was and I'll never do it again. That's one good thing about me. I never do the same naughty thing twice.
Marilla Cuthbert: You didn't put it back, That brooch isn't anywhere on the bureau. You've taken it out or something, Anne.
Anne Shirley: I did put it back, I don't just remember whether I stuck it on the pincushion or laid it in the china tray. But I'm perfectly certain I put it back.
Marilla Cuthbert: I'll go and have another look, If you put that brooch back it's there still. If it isn't I'll know you didn't, that's all!
Marilla Cuthbert: Anne, the brooch is gone. By your own admission you were the last person to handle it. Now, what have you done with it? Tell me the truth at once. Did you take it out and lose it?
Anne Shirley: No, I didn't, I never took the brooch out of your room and that is the truth, if I was to be led to the block for it--although I'm not very certain what a block is. So there, Marilla.
Marilla Cuthbert: I believe you are telling me a falsehood, Anne, I know you are. There now, don't say anything more unless you are prepared to tell the whole truth. Go to your room and stay there until you are ready to confess.
Anne Shirley: Will I take the peas with me?
Marilla Cuthbert: No, I'll finish shelling them myself. Do as I bid you.
Marilla Cuthbert: I don't know what I wouldn't sooner have had happen, Of course, I don't suppose she meant to steal it or anything like that. She's just taken it to play with or help along that imagination of hers. She must have taken it, that's clear, for there hasn't been a soul in that room since she was in it, by her own story, until I went up tonight. And the brooch is gone, there's nothing surer. I suppose she has lost it and is afraid to own up for fear she'll be punished. It's a dreadful thing to think she tells falsehoods. It's a far worse thing than her fit of temper. It's a fearful responsibility to have a child in your house you can't trust. Slyness and untruthfulness--that's what she has displayed. I declare I feel worse about that than about the brooch. If she'd only have told the truth about it I wouldn't mind so much.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Matthew Cuthbert: You're sure it hasn't fell down behind the bureau?

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Diana Barry: Sweet-natured and loyal, easily swept up in excitement, with a gentle manner and deep affection for those she loves.
Anne Shirley: Imaginative and expressive, speaking in vivid, poetic language, full of enthusiasm and deep emotions, with a tendency for dramatic flourishes.
Marilla Cuthbert: Practical and stern, with a dry wit and deep sense of duty, masking a heart that is far softer than she lets on.
Mrs. Barry: Strict and protective, prone to overreacting to perceived threats, especially when it comes to her daughter.
Matthew Cuthbert: Quiet and deeply kind, speaking sparingly but always with sincerity, preferring to listen rather than lead conversations.


Dialogue History: Anne Shirley: There wasn't anything startling in that, was there, Marilla?
Mrs. Barry: This is my little girl Diana, Diana, you might take Anne out into the garden and show her your flowers. It will be better for you than straining your eyes over that book. She reads entirely too much--
Mrs. Barry: and I can't prevent her, for her father aids and abets her. She's always poring over a book. I'm glad she has the prospect of a playmate--perhaps it will take her more out-of-doors.
Anne Shirley: Oh, Diana, oh, do you think you can like me a little--enough to be my bosom friend?
Diana Barry: Why, I guess so, I'm awfully glad you've come to live at Green Gables. It will be jolly to have somebody to play with. There isn't any other girl who lives near enough to play with, and I've no sisters big enough.
Anne Shirley: Will you swear to be my friend forever and ever?
Diana Barry: Why it's dreadfully wicked to swear,
Anne Shirley: Oh no, not my kind of swearing. There are two kinds, you know.
Diana Barry: I never heard of but one kind,
Anne Shirley: There really is another. Oh, it isn't wicked at all. It just means vowing and promising solemnly.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Diana Barry: Well, I don't mind doing that, How do you do it?

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Diana Barry: Sweet-natured and loyal, easily swept up in excitement, with a gentle manner and deep affection for those she loves.
Marilla Cuthbert: Practical and stern, with a dry wit and deep sense of duty, masking a heart that is far softer than she lets on.
Mrs. Barry: Strict and protective, prone to overreacting to perceived threats, especially when it comes to her daughter.
Anne Shirley: Imaginative and expressive, speaking in vivid, poetic language, full of enthusiasm and deep emotions, with a tendency for dramatic flourishes.


Dialogue History: Anne Shirley: I never tasted it, I thought it was the cordial. I meant to be so--so--hospitable. Diana got awfully sick and had to go home. Mrs. Barry told Mrs. Lynde she was simply dead drunk. She just laughed silly-like when her mother asked her what was the matter and went to sleep and slept for hours. Her mother smelled her breath and knew she was drunk. She had a fearful headache all day yesterday. Mrs. Barry is so indignant. She will never believe but what I did it on purpose.
Marilla Cuthbert: I should think she would better punish Diana for being so greedy as to drink three glassfuls of anything, Why, three of those big glasses would have made her sick even if it had only been cordial. Well, this story will be a nice handle for those folks who are so down on me for making currant wine, although I haven't made any for three years ever since I found out that the minister didn't approve. I just kept that bottle for sickness. There, there, child, don't cry. I can't see as you were to blame although I'm sorry it happened so.
Anne Shirley: I must cry, My heart is broken. The stars in their courses fight against me, Marilla. Diana and I are parted forever. Oh, Marilla, I little dreamed of this when first we swore our vows of friendship.
Marilla Cuthbert: Don't be foolish, Anne. Mrs. Barry will think better of it when she finds you're not to blame. I suppose she thinks you've done it for a silly joke or something of that sort. You'd best go up this evening and tell her how it was.
Anne Shirley: My courage fails me at the thought of facing Diana's injured mother, I wish you'd go, Marilla. You're so much more dignified than I am. Likely she'd listen to you quicker than to me.
Marilla Cuthbert: Well, I will, Don't cry any more, Anne. It will be all right.
Anne Shirley: Oh, Marilla, I know by your face that it's been no use, Mrs. Barry won't forgive me?
Marilla Cuthbert: Mrs. Barry indeed! Of all the unreasonable women I ever saw she's the worst. I told her it was all a mistake and you weren't to blame, but she just simply didn't believe me. And she rubbed it well in about my currant wine and how I'd always said it couldn't have the least effect on anybody. I just told her plainly that currant wine wasn't meant to be drunk three tumblerfuls at a time and that if a child I had to do with was so greedy I'd sober her up with a right good spanking.
Mrs. Barry: What do you want?
Anne Shirley: Oh, Mrs. Barry, please forgive me. I did not mean to--to--intoxicate Diana. How could I? Just imagine if you were a poor little orphan girl that kind people had adopted and you had just one bosom friend in all the world. Do you think you would intoxicate her on purpose? I thought it was only raspberry cordial. I was firmly convinced it was raspberry cordial. Oh, please don't say that you won't let Diana play with me any more. If you do you will cover my life with a dark cloud of woe.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Mrs. Barry: I don't think you are a fit little girl for Diana to associate with. You'd better go home and behave yourself.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Anne Shirley: Imaginative and expressive, speaking in vivid, poetic language, full of enthusiasm and deep emotions, with a tendency for dramatic flourishes.
The Station-Master: Brisk and efficient, focused on his work with little patience for idle chatter, though not unkind.
Matthew Cuthbert: Quiet and deeply kind, speaking sparingly but always with sincerity, preferring to listen rather than lead conversations.


Dialogue History: The Station-Master: The five-thirty train has been in and gone half an hour ago, But there was a passenger dropped off for you--a little girl. She's sitting out there on the shingles. I asked her to go into the ladies' waiting room, but she informed me gravely that she preferred to stay outside. she said. She's a case, I should say.
Matthew Cuthbert: I'm not expecting a girl, It's a boy I've come for. He should be here. Mrs. Alexander Spencer was to bring him over from Nova Scotia for me.
The Station-Master: Guess there's some mistake, Mrs. Spencer came off the train with that girl and gave her into my charge. Said you and your sister were adopting her from an orphan asylum and that you would be along for her presently. That's all I know about it--and I haven't got any more orphans concealed hereabouts.
Matthew Cuthbert: I don't understand,
The Station-Master: Well, you'd better question the girl, I dare say she'll be able to explain--she's got a tongue of her own, that's certain. Maybe they were out of boys of the brand you wanted.
Anne Shirley: I suppose you are Mr. Matthew Cuthbert of Green Gables? I'm very glad to see you. I was beginning to be afraid you weren't coming for me and I was imagining all the things that might have happened to prevent you. I had made up my mind that if you didn't come for me to-night I'd go down the track to that big wild cherry-tree at the bend, and climb up into it to stay all night. I wouldn't be a bit afraid, and it would be lovely to sleep in a wild cherry-tree all white with bloom in the moonshine, don't you think? You could imagine you were dwelling in marble halls, couldn't you? And I was quite sure you would come for me in the morning, if you didn't to-night.
Matthew Cuthbert: I'm sorry I was late, Come along. The horse is over in the yard. Give me your bag.
Anne Shirley: Oh, I can carry it, It isn't heavy. I've got all my worldly goods in it, but it isn't heavy. And if it isn't carried in just a certain way the handle pulls out--so I'd better keep it because I know the exact knack of it. It's an extremely old carpet-bag. Oh, I'm very glad you've come, even if it would have been nice to sleep in a wild cherry-tree. We've got to drive a long piece, haven't we? Mrs. Spencer said it was eight miles. I'm glad because I love driving. Oh, it seems so wonderful that I'm going to live with you and belong to you. I've never belonged to anybody--not really. But the asylum was the worst. I've only been in it four months, but that was enough. I don't suppose you ever were an orphan in an asylum, so you can't possibly understand what it is like. It's worse than anything you could imagine. Mrs. Spencer said it was wicked of me to talk like that, but I didn't mean to be wicked. It's so easy to be wicked without knowing it, isn't it? They were good, you know--the asylum people. But there is so little scope for the imagination in an asylum--only just in the other orphans. It was pretty interesting to imagine things about them--to imagine that perhaps the girl who sat next to you was really the daughter of a belted earl, who had been stolen away from her parents in her infancy by a cruel nurse who died before she could confess. I used to lie awake at nights and imagine things like that, because I didn't have time in the day. I guess that's why I'm so thin--I _am_ dreadful thin, ain't I? There isn't a pick on my bones. I do love to imagine I'm nice and plump, with dimples in my elbows.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Anne Shirley: Isn't that beautiful? What did that tree, leaning out from the bank, all white and lacy, make you think of?

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Anne Shirley: Imaginative and expressive, speaking in vivid, poetic language, full of enthusiasm and deep emotions, with a tendency for dramatic flourishes.
Marilla Cuthbert: Practical and stern, with a dry wit and deep sense of duty, masking a heart that is far softer than she lets on.
Matthew Cuthbert: Quiet and deeply kind, speaking sparingly but always with sincerity, preferring to listen rather than lead conversations.


Dialogue History: Anne Shirley: Look at my hair, Marilla,
Marilla Cuthbert: Anne Shirley, what have you done to your hair? Why, it's _green!_
Anne Shirley: Yes, it's green, I thought nothing could be as bad as red hair. But now I know it's ten times worse to have green hair. Oh, Marilla, you little know how utterly wretched I am.
Marilla Cuthbert: I little know how you got into this fix, but I mean to find out, Come right down to the kitchen--it's too cold up here--and tell me just what you've done. I've been expecting something queer for some time. You haven't got into any scrape for over two months, and I was sure another one was due. Now, then, what did you do to your hair?
Anne Shirley: I dyed it.
Marilla Cuthbert: Dyed it! Dyed your hair! Anne Shirley, didn't you know it was a wicked thing to do?
Anne Shirley: Yes, I knew it was a little wicked, But I thought it was worth while to be a little wicked to get rid of red hair. I counted the cost, Marilla. Besides, I meant to be extra good in other ways to make up for it.
Marilla Cuthbert: Well, if I'd decided it was worth while to dye my hair I'd have dyed it a decent color at least. I wouldn't have dyed it green.
Anne Shirley: But I didn't mean to dye it green, Marilla, If I was wicked I meant to be wicked to some purpose. He said it would turn my hair a beautiful raven black--he positively assured me that it would. How could I doubt his word, Marilla? I know what it feels like to have your word doubted. And Mrs. Allan says we should never suspect anyone of not telling us the truth unless we have proof that they're not. I have proof now--green hair is proof enough for anybody. But I hadn't then and I believed every word he said _implicitly_.
Marilla Cuthbert: Who said? Who are you talking about?

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Anne Shirley: The peddler that was here this afternoon. I bought the dye from him.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Rachel Lynde: Blunt and opinionated, never hesitating to voice her thoughts, but ultimately well-meaning and fiercely loyal to those she cares for.
Diana Barry: Sweet-natured and loyal, easily swept up in excitement, with a gentle manner and deep affection for those she loves.
Anne Shirley: Imaginative and expressive, speaking in vivid, poetic language, full of enthusiasm and deep emotions, with a tendency for dramatic flourishes.
Marilla Cuthbert: Practical and stern, with a dry wit and deep sense of duty, masking a heart that is far softer than she lets on.
Mrs. Barry: Strict and protective, prone to overreacting to perceived threats, especially when it comes to her daughter.
Matthew Cuthbert: Quiet and deeply kind, speaking sparingly but always with sincerity, preferring to listen rather than lead conversations.
Aunt Josephine: Wealthy and eccentric, initially gruff but ultimately kind-hearted, enjoying a sharp wit and a taste for adventure in her old age.


Dialogue History: Aunt Josephine: Who are you?
Anne Shirley: I'm Anne of Green Gables, and I've come to confess, if you please.
Aunt Josephine: Confess what?
Anne Shirley: That it was all my fault about jumping into bed on you last night. I suggested it. Diana would never have thought of such a thing, I am sure. Diana is a very ladylike girl, Miss Barry. So you must see how unjust it is to blame her.
Aunt Josephine: Oh, I must, hey? I rather think Diana did her share of the jumping at least. Such carryings on in a respectable house!
Anne Shirley: But we were only in fun, I think you ought to forgive us, Miss Barry, now that we've apologized. And anyhow, please forgive Diana and let her have her music lessons. Diana's heart is set on her music lessons, Miss Barry, and I know too well what it is to set your heart on a thing and not get it. If you must be cross with anyone, be cross with me. I've been so used in my early days to having people cross at me that I can endure it much better than Diana can.
Aunt Josephine: I don't think it is any excuse for you that you were only in fun. Little girls never indulged in that kind of fun when I was young. You don't know what it is to be awakened out of a sound sleep, after a long and arduous journey, by two great girls coming bounce down on you.
Anne Shirley: I don't _know_, but I can _imagine_, I'm sure it must have been very disturbing. But then, there is our side of it too. Have you any imagination, Miss Barry? If you have, just put yourself in our place. We didn't know there was anybody in that bed and you nearly scared us to death. It was simply awful the way we felt. And then we couldn't sleep in the spare room after being promised. I suppose you are used to sleeping in spare rooms. But just imagine what you would feel like if you were a little orphan girl who had never had such an honor.
Aunt Josephine: I'm afraid my imagination is a little rusty--it's so long since I used it, I dare say your claim to sympathy is just as strong as mine. It all depends on the way we look at it. Sit down here and tell me about yourself.
Anne Shirley: I am very sorry I can't, I would like to, because you seem like an interesting lady, and you might even be a kindred spirit although you don't look very much like it. But it is my duty to go home to Miss Marilla Cuthbert. Miss Marilla Cuthbert is a very kind lady who has taken me to bring up properly. She is doing her best, but it is very discouraging work. You must not blame her because I jumped on the bed. But before I go I do wish you would tell me if you will forgive Diana and stay just as long as you meant to in Avonlea.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Aunt Josephine: I think perhaps I will if you will come over and talk to me occasionally,

 [/INST]
ground_truth: Marilla Cuthbert: Yes, I saw him. He examined my eyes. prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Gilbert Blythe: Charming and mischievous, quick-witted in conversation, competitive yet kind-hearted, with a knack for teasing those he admires.
Marilla Cuthbert: Practical and stern, with a dry wit and deep sense of duty, masking a heart that is far softer than she lets on.
Rachel Lynde: Blunt and opinionated, never hesitating to voice her thoughts, but ultimately well-meaning and fiercely loyal to those she cares for.
Anne Shirley: Imaginative and expressive, speaking in vivid, poetic language, full of enthusiasm and deep emotions, with a tendency for dramatic flourishes.


Dialogue History: Anne Shirley: Are you very tired, Marilla?
Marilla Cuthbert: Yes--no--I don't know, I suppose I am tired but I haven't thought about it. It's not that.
Anne Shirley: Did you see the oculist? What did he say?
Marilla Cuthbert: Yes, I saw him. He examined my eyes. He says that if I give up all reading and sewing entirely and any kind of work that strains the eyes, and if I'm careful not to cry, and if I wear the glasses he's given me he thinks my eyes may not get any worse and my headaches will be cured. But if I don't he says I'll certainly be stone-blind in six months. Blind! Anne, just think of it!
Anne Shirley: Marilla, _don't_ think of it. You know he has given you hope. If you are careful you won't lose your sight altogether; and if his glasses cure your headaches it will be a great thing.
Marilla Cuthbert: I don't call it much hope, What am I to live for if I can't read or sew or do anything like that? I might as well be blind--or dead. And as for crying, I can't help that when I get lonesome. But there, it's no good talking about it. If you'll get me a cup of tea I'll be thankful. I'm about done out. Don't say anything about this to any one for a spell yet, anyway. I can't bear that folks should come here to question and sympathize and talk about it.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Anne Shirley: What did Mr. Sadler want, Marilla?
